snippet.textDisplay:
Great job!
I would like to see a test of how well they communicate with other devices over HDMI. My LG uses Simplink and it’s TERRIBLE. The TV rarely turns off when I turn my Apple TV off. My old Sony worked every single time and my really old Samsung always worked as well.

snippet.textDisplay: Too bad the image quality on the Sceptre is so disappointing. I'd love to see more affordable non "smart" TVs that skip all of the adware and data mining (not to mention the risk of issues when they stop getting updates in a couple of years). When I bought my 4K TV a few years ago, there were not really any good non-smart options. As I describe it, it's a crappy low end smartphone with an amazing screen. I still dread the day the software takes a shit and I'm unable to use the TV (rather than just replacing the Shield or old laptop I'd have hooked up).
snippet.textOriginal: Too bad the image quality on the Sceptre is so disappointing.  I'd love to see more affordable *non* "smart" TVs that skip all of the adware and data mining (not to mention the risk of issues when they stop getting updates in a couple of years).  When I bought my 4K TV a few years ago, there were not really any good non-smart options.  As I describe it, it's a crappy low end smartphone with an amazing screen.  I still dread the day the software takes a shit and I'm unable to use the TV (rather than just replacing the Shield or old laptop I'd have hooked up).

snippet.textDisplay: simple version for say a hisense q7 7809 ? if you plug it on pc . make sure you got a bt2020 color profile on the pc ( you need to right click it once downloaded and unlock it) then you need to check gpu and make sure ycbcr 4.2.2 is enabled not srgb. and make sure 10 bit color is enabled . once that is done you enable hdr . and you restart your tv and computer ! if the first image you see is less then expected . say you baught a 21060p 60 hertz tv and it only say 2160p 30 hertz you did something wrong somewhere ! anyway . once you have done this ? and followed tv maker instruction . you should have an awsome image. oh ya when you enable hdr make sure both image at bottom are fairly similar or standard or hdr will be darker ! ( usually midway ( 50 ) is a good starting point) i dont know if linus knew this . i didnt see a video of him explaining pc and uhd together like i just mentioned . its a very short version . you might also need to set color profile to absolute instead !
snippet.textOriginal: simple version for say a hisense q7 7809 ? if you plug it on pc . make sure you got a bt2020 color profile on the pc ( you need to right click it once downloaded and unlock it) then you need to check gpu and make sure ycbcr 4.2.2 is enabled not srgb. and make sure 10 bit color is enabled . once that is done you enable hdr . and you restart your tv and computer ! if the first image you see is less then expected . say you baught a 21060p 60 hertz tv and it only say 2160p 30 hertz you did something wrong somewhere ! anyway . once you have done this ? and followed tv maker instruction . you should have an awsome image. oh ya when you enable hdr make sure both image at bottom are fairly similar or standard or hdr will be darker ! ( usually midway ( 50 ) is a good starting point) i dont know if linus knew this . i didnt see a video of him explaining pc and uhd together like i just mentioned . its a very short version . you might also need to set color profile to absolute instead !

snippet.textDisplay: Not totally sure on this, but you might be able to enable Dolby Vision in the Samsung Service Mode.  I know there have been features on other cheaper models that you could enable through Service Mode.  You need a regular Samsung remote to get there, but it's pretty easy to do.  With it in standby, you hit Info | Menu | Mute | Power  in sequence and it should load the Service Mode.  Just be careful because you can really screw things up in there.
snippet.textOriginal: Not totally sure on this, but you might be able to enable Dolby Vision in the Samsung Service Mode.  I know there have been features on other cheaper models that you could enable through Service Mode.  You need a regular Samsung remote to get there, but it's pretty easy to do.  With it in standby, you hit Info | Menu | Mute | Power  in sequence and it should load the Service Mode.  Just be careful because you can really screw things up in there.

snippet.textDisplay:
Love that linus doesn't understand how to use the settings bar to enable game mode. 1%er confirmed got to big to be an every day tech guru.

LG and Samsung have per input settings. So when you changed all the settings while no active device is in use it will not change anything. TCL forces you to change while in the input rather than letting you think you are changing it.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm using Hisense's 4k 43" TV
Hisense h43be7200

I can recommend it.
VA-Panel, 8bit + FRC ("10bit")
so no native HDR, but support (only a few tests with youtube so I can't say much about it)
responsive remote control
fast startup (standby and power off, power off being slower but not unbearably so)

no WiFI 5GHz
GUI is upscaled from something that might even be below Full HD :/ (doesn't look as sharp as it should, subtitles for Netflix etc. too)
no motion smoothing technique at all (might be positive ^^)
snippet.textOriginal:
I'm using Hisense's 4k 43" TV
Hisense h43be7200

I can recommend it.
VA-Panel, 8bit + FRC ("10bit")
so no native HDR, but support (only a few tests with youtube so I can't say much about it)
responsive remote control
fast startup (standby and power off, power off being slower but not unbearably so)

no WiFI 5GHz
GUI is upscaled from something that might even be below Full HD :/ (doesn't look as sharp as it should, subtitles for Netflix etc. too)
no motion smoothing technique at all (might be positive ^^)

snippet.textDisplay:
about wrong hdr marketing: that's what the ultra hd premium logo on the box is for ;)
That's how you can make sure, that hdr will be working correctly.

The rest is "hdr support", which might actually be good in other ways:
simple 10bit decoding support.
8bit encoded in 10bit can remain smaller (bitrate-wise) than 8bit in 8bit and doesn't have banding issues.

Netflix and YouTube might make AV1 10bit encodings because of that (depends on hardware decoders -> "hdr support" even in low-end devices)
snippet.textOriginal:
about wrong hdr marketing: that's what the ultra hd premium logo on the box is for ;)
That's how you can make sure, that hdr will be working correctly.

The rest is "hdr support", which might actually be good in other ways:
simple 10bit decoding support.
8bit encoded in 10bit can remain smaller (bitrate-wise) than 8bit in 8bit and doesn't have banding issues.

Netflix and YouTube might make AV1 10bit encodings because of that (depends on hardware decoders -> "hdr support" even in low-end devices)

snippet.textDisplay: "You can't" do screen mirroring on the Samsung is completely wrong. not only does it work with android screencasting, but it also has apple airplay aswell. Maybe you should try things before just assuming that it cant. As soon as you connect the tv to the internet it will be detected as an available device to cast to on your phone or tablet. Maybe you should look more into things before you have a video about it. Samsung wouldn't lie about something or else they would get sued. And if you actually took the time to look through the menus better. I have to say some of the menus are a bit confusing, however, you can manually turn on and off game mode and low latency.
snippet.textOriginal: "You can't" do screen mirroring on the Samsung is completely wrong. not only does it work with android screencasting, but it also has apple airplay aswell. Maybe you should try things before just assuming that it cant. As soon as you connect the tv to the internet it will be detected as an available device to cast to on your phone or tablet. Maybe you should look more into things before you have a video about it. Samsung wouldn't lie about something or else they would get sued. And if you actually took the time to look through the menus better. I have to say some of the menus are a bit confusing, however, you can manually turn on and off game mode and low latency.

snippet.textDisplay: For those of you who have a 1080p TV wondering if you should get a 4k, the answer is not yet. At least wait for the PS5. A year after or even later would be better. Video player manufacturers do NOT let you know when it's time to upgrade. ISP download speed, internet stream servicess like Netflix 4k content library, and video game console manufacturers set the trend.
snippet.textOriginal: For those of you who have a 1080p TV wondering if you should get a 4k, the answer is not yet. At least wait for the PS5. A year after or even later would be better. Video player manufacturers do NOT let you know when it's time to upgrade. ISP download speed, internet stream servicess like Netflix 4k content library, and video game console manufacturers set the trend.
